Cornell, Svante (2006). The Politicization of Islam in Azerbaijan. Silk Road Paper. pp. 124, 222, 229, 269\xe2\x80\x93270.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Routledge-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Routledge_13-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFYilmaz2015" class="citation book">Yilmaz, Harun (2015). <i>National Identities in Soviet Historiography: The Rise of Nations Under Stalin</i>. Routledge. p.&#160;21. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-1-317-59664-6" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-1-317-59664-6"><bdi>978-1-317-59664-6</bdi></a>. <q>On May 27, the Democratic Republic of Azerbaijan (DRA) was declared with Ottoman military support. The rulers of the DRA refused to identify themselves as [Transcaucasian] Tatar, which they rightfully considered to be a Russian colonial definition. (...) Neighboring Iran did not welcome the DRA\'s adoption of the name of "Azerbaijan" for the country because it could also refer to Iranian Azerbaijan and implied a territorial claim.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=National+Identities+in+Soviet+Historiography%3A+The+Rise+of+Nations+Under+Stalin&amp;rft.pages=21&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2015&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-59664-6&amp;rft.aulast=Yilmaz&amp;rft.aufirst=Harun&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Sochineniya,_vol_II/1-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Sochineniya,_vol_II/1_14-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFBarthold1963" class="citation book">Barthold, Vasily (1963). <i>Sochineniya, vol II/1</i>. Moscow. p.&#160;706. <q>(...) whenever it is necessary to choose a name that will encompass all regions of the Republic of Azerbaijan, name <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arran_(Caucasus)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arran (Caucasus) (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Arran</a> can be chosen. But the term Azerbaijan was chosen because when the Azerbaijan republic was created, it was assumed that this and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iranian_Azerbaijan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iranian Azerbaijan (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Persian Azerbaijan</a> would be one entity because the population of both has a big similarity. On this basis, the word Azerbaijan was chosen. Of course right now when the word Azerbaijan is used, it has two meanings as Persian Azerbaijan and as a republic, its confusing and a question arises as to which Azerbaijan is talked about.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Sochineniya%2C+vol+II%2F1&amp;rft.place=Moscow&amp;rft.pages=706&amp;rft.date=1963&amp;rft.aulast=Barthold&amp;rft.aufirst=Vasily&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-I.B.Tauris2-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-I.B.Tauris2_15-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFAtabaki2000" class="citation book">Atabaki, Touraj (2000). <i>Azerbaijan: Ethnicity and the Struggle for Power in Iran</i>. I.B.Tauris. p.&#160;25. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-1-86064-554-9" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-1-86064-554-9"><bdi>978-1-86064-554-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Azerbaijan%3A+Ethnicity+and+the+Struggle+for+Power+in+Iran&amp;rft.pages=25&amp;rft.pub=I.B.Tauris&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-86064-554-9&amp;rft.aulast=Atabaki&amp;rft.aufirst=Touraj&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-I.B._Tauris2-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-I.B._Tauris2_16-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFDekmejianSimonian2003" class="citation book">Dekmejian, R. Hrair; Simonian, Hovann H. (2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=4_jdnke35AgC"><i>Troubled Waters: The Geopolitics of the Caspian Region</i></a>. I.B. Tauris. p.&#160;60. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-1-86064-922-6" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-1-86064-922-6"><bdi>978-1-86064-922-6</bdi></a>. <q>Until 1918, when the Musavat regime decided to name the newly independent state Azerbaijan, this designation had been used exclusively to identify the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iranian_Azerbaijan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iranian Azerbaijan (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Iranian province of Azerbaijan</a>.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Troubled+Waters%3A+The+Geopolitics+of+the+Caspian+Region&amp;rft.pages=60&amp;rft.pub=I.B.+Tauris&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-86064-922-6&amp;rft.aulast=Dekmejian&amp;rft.aufirst=R.+Hrair&amp;rft.au=Simonian%2C+Hovann+H.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D4_jdnke35AgC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Amsterdam_University_Press2-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Amsterdam_University_Press2_17-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFRezvani2014" class="citation book">Rezvani, Babak (2014). <i>Ethno-territorial conflict and coexistence in the Caucasus, Central Asia and Fereydan: academisch proefschrift</i>. Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press. p.&#160;356. <a title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-9048519286" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 northwestern Iran that has been called since so long ago.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ethno-territorial+conflict+and+coexistence+in+the+Caucasus%2C+Central+Asia+and+Fereydan%3A+academisch+proefschrift&amp;rft.place=Amsterdam&amp;rft.pages=356&amp;rft.pub=Amsterdam+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-9048519286&amp;rft.aulast=Rezvani&amp;rft.aufirst=Babak&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" href="#cite_ref-20">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFPipes1997" class="citation book"><a href="/wiki/Richard_Pipes" class="mw-redirect" title="Richard Pipes">Pipes, Richard</a> (1997). <i>The Formation of the Soviet Union: Communism and Nationalism 1917\xe2\x80\x931923</i> (2nd ed.). Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press. pp.&#160;218\xe2\x80\x93220, 229. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-0-674-30951-7" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-0-674-30951-7"><bdi>978-0-674-30951-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Formation+of+the+Soviet+Union%3A+Communism+and+Nationalism+1917%E2%80%931923&amp;rft.place=Cambridge%2C+Massachusetts&amp;rft.pages=218-220%2C+229&amp;rft.edition=2nd&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-30951-7&amp;rft.aulast=Pipes&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-21">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFKing2006" class="citation book">King, David C. (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/azerbaijan00king/page/27"><i>Azerbaijan</i></a>. id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-25">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.hrw.org/europecentral-asia/azerbaijan">"Azerbaijan | Country Page | World | Human Rights Watch"</a>. <i>www.hrw.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2021-10-06</span></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.hrw.org&amp;rft.atitle=Azerbaijan+%7C+Country+Page+%7C+World+%7C+Human+Rights+Watch&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.hrw.org%2Feuropecentral-asia%2Fazerbaijan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-:3-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-:3_26-0">\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb6\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-:3_26-1">\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb6\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFCornell2010" class="citation book">Cornell, Svante E. (2010). <i>Azerbaijan Since Independence</i>. M.E. Sharpe. pp.&#160;165, 284. <q>Indicative of general regional trends and a natural reemergence of previously oppressed religious identity, an increasingly popular ideological basis for the pursuit of political objectives has been Islam.... The government, for its part, has shown an official commitment to Islam by building mosques and respecting Islamic values... Unofficial Islamic groups sought to use aspects of Islam to mobilize the population and establish the foundations for a future political struggle.... Unlike Turkey, Azerbaijan does not have the powerful ideological legacy of secularism... the conflict with Armenia has bred frustration that is increasingly being answered by a combined Islamic and nationalist sentiment, especially among younger people... All major political forces are committed to secularism and are based, if anything, on a nationalist agenda.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Azerbaijan+Since+Independence&amp;rft.pages=165%2C+284&amp;rft.pub=M.E.+Sharpe&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.aulast=Cornell&amp;rft.aufirst=Svante+E.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-FCO-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-FCO_27-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070609103711/http://www.fco.gov.uk/servlet/Front?pagename=OpenMarket%2FXcelerate%2FShowPage&amp;c=Page&amp;cid=1007029394365&amp;a=KCountryProfile&amp;aid=1019233781986">"Azerbaijan: Membership of international groupings/organisations"</a>. British Foreign &amp; Commonwealth Office. Routledge. p.&#160;154. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-1-85743-058-5" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-1-85743-058-5"><bdi>978-1-85743-058-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Eastern+Europe+and+the+Commonwealth+of+Independent+States&amp;rft.pages=154&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-85743-058-5&amp;rft.au=Europa+Publications+Limited&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-29">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFHoutsma1993" class="citation book"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Martijn_Theodoor_Houtsma&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martijn Theodoor Houtsma (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Houtsma, M. Th.</a> (1993). <i>First Encyclopaedia of Islam 1913\xe2\x80\x931936</i> (reprint ed.). Brill Online.</a><sup class="Fix-tag"><sup class="noprint Inline-Template"><span title="" style="white-space: nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%A9%DB%8C%E2%80%8C%D9%BE%D8%AF%DB%8C%D8%A7:%D9%BE%DB%8C%D9%88%D9%86%D8%AF%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%87" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\xa9\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd9\xbe\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7:\xd9\xbe\xdb\x8c\xd9\x88\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87">\xd9\xbe\xdb\x8c\xd9\x88\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf \xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87</a></i>&#93;</span></sup></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-39">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book"><i>\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</i>. \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xda\xa9\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd9\x84\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaf\xd9\x87\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xd9\x86\xd9\x88. <bdi>\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb4</bdi>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86&amp;rft.pub=%D8%A7%D8%B3%DA%A9%D8%A7%DB%8C+%D9%84%DB%8C%D9%86+%D8%AF%D9%87%D9%84%DB%8C+%D9%86%D9%88&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290294"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-40">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Minorsky, V.&#160;; Minorsky, V. "\xc4\x80dharbaydj\xc4\x81n (Azarb\xc4\x81ydj\xc4\x81n)." Encyclopaedia of Islam. Edited by: P.Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel and W.P. Heinrichs. Brill, 2007. Brill Online\n\xe2\x80\x9c called in Middle Persian \xc4\x80turp\xc4\x81t\xc4\x81k\xc4\x81n, older new-Persian \xc4\x80d\xcc\xb2h\xcc\xb2arb\xc4\x81d\xcc\xb2h\xcc\xb2ag\xc4\x81n, \xc4\x80d\xcc\xb2h\xcc\xb2arb\xc4\x81yag\xc4\x81n, at present \xc4\x80zarb\xc4\x81yd\xcc\xb2j\xcc\xb2\xc4\x81n, Greek \xe1\xbe\xbf\xce\x91\xcf\x84\xcf\x81\xce\xbf\xcf\x80\xce\xb1\xcf\x84\xce\xae\xce\xbd\xce\xb7, Byzantine Greek \xe1\xbe\xbf\xce\x91\xce\xb4\xcf\x81\xce\xb1\xce\xb2\xce\xb9\xce\xb3\xce\xac\xce\xbd\xcf\x89\xce\xbd, Armenian Atrapatakan, Syriac Ad\xcc\xb2h\xcc\xb2orb\xc4\x81yg\xcc\xb2h\xcc\xb2\xc4\x81n. The province was called after the general Atropates (\xe2\x80\x9cprotected by fire\xe2\x80\x9d), who at the time of Alexander\'s invasion proclaimed his independence (328 B.C.) and thus preserved his kingdom (Media Minor, Strabo, xi, 13, 1) in the north-western corner of later Persia (cf. Ibn al-Mu\xe1\xb8\xb3affa\xca\xbf, in Y\xc4\x81\xe1\xb8\xb3\xc5\xabt, i, 172, and al-Ma\xe1\xb8\xb3dis\xc4\xab, 375: \xc4\x80d\xcc\xb2h\xcc\xb2arb\xc4\x81d\xcc\xb2h\xcc\xb2 b. B\xc4\xabwarasf).</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-41">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">K. Shippman, "Azerbaijan: Pre-Islamic History" in Encyclop\xc3\xa6dia Iranica\nIn the Achaemenid period Azerbaijan was part of the satrapy of Media. When the Achaemenid empire collapsed, Atropates, the Persian satrap of Media, made himself independent in the northwest of this region in 321 B.C. Thereafter Greek and Latin writers named the territory Media Atropatene or, less frequently, Media Minor (e.g. Strabo 11.13.1; Justin 23.4.13). The Middle Persian form of the name was (early) \xc4\x80turp\xc4\x81t\xc4\x81k\xc4\x81n, (later) \xc4\x80durb\xc4\x81dg\xc4\x81n) whence the New Persian \xc4\x80darb\xc4\x81yj\xc4\x81n</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-dreza-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-dreza_42-0">\xdb\xb4\xdb\xb2\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-dreza_42-1">\xdb\xb4\xdb\xb2\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-dreza_42-2">\xdb\xb4\xdb\xb2\xd9\xab\xdb\xb2</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb6\xd8\xa7\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb9\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xaa \xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xd9\x87\xd8\x8c \xc2\xab\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb4\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xc2\xbb\xd8\x8c <a href="/wiki/%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B1%D8%A9%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%81_%D8%A8%D8%B2%D8%B1%DA%AF_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85%DB%8C" title="\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa6\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa9\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x81 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xb2\xd8\xb1\xda\xaf \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c">\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa6\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa9\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x81 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xb2\xd8\xb1\xda\xaf \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c</a>\xd8\x8c \xd8\xac\xd9\x84\xd8\xaf \xdb\xb1\xd8\x8c \xda\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\xbe \xd8\xa7\xd9\x88\xd9\x84: \xd8\xaa\xd9\x87\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\x8c \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb6\xdb\xb7 \xd8\xb4\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb5\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb7\xe2\x80\x93\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb4\xdb\xb3</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-43">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xda\xa9\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\x9f\xd8\x8c \xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaa\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xac\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84 \xd9\x85\xd8\xaa\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xd8\x8c \xd9\x86\xd8\xb4\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\x8c \xd9\xbe\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb2 1368\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb3\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84 \xd8\xa7\xd9\x88\xd9\x84\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xb3\xd9\x88\xd9\x85\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb5\xd8\xb5 462-443</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-44">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">I. Ovchinnikov, "The Test is Canceled, History Reminded!", Izvestia, The Current Digest of the Soviet Press, XL, No. 23, 1988, P.22, Moskva, June 10 1988</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-45">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">\xd9\x85\xd8\xad\xd8\xb3\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xd8\x8c \xd9\x85\xd8\xad\xd9\x85\xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb6\xd8\xa7 \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb9: <i>\xd9\xbe\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1\xda\xa9\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb3\xd9\x85\xd8\x8c \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</i>\xd8\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb4\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd8\xb3\xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xd9\x82\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb5\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb1</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-46">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaf\xd9\x88 \xd9\xbe\xdb\x8c\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x85\xd8\xac\xd9\x84\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\x8c \xd8\xac \xdb\xb1\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xdb\xb3\xd8\x8c \xda\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\xbe \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb9\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb9\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xdb\xb4\xdb\xb5\xdb\xb8 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xad\xd8\xaa \xd8\xb9\xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xc2\xab\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xda\xa9\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xc2\xbb \xd8\xaa\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3\xd8\xb7 \xd8\xac\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84 \xd9\x85\xd8\xaa\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c \xda\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\xbe \xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Atabaki2006-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Atabaki2006_47-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFAtabaki2006" class="citation book"><a 2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=M3adD9kNH1gC&amp;pg=PA132"><i>Iran and the First World War: Battleground of the Great Powers</i></a>. I.B.Tauris. p.&#160;132. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-1-86064-964-6" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-1-86064-964-6"><bdi>978-1-86064-964-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Iran+and+the+First+World+War%3A+Battleground+of+the+Great+Powers&amp;rft.pages=132&amp;rft.pub=I.B.Tauris&amp;rft.date=2006-09-04&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-86064-964-6&amp;rft.aulast=Atabaki&amp;rft.aufirst=Touraj&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DM3adD9kNH1gC%26pg%3DPA132&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-I.B.Tauris-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-I.B.Tauris_48-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFAtabaki2000" class="citation book">Atabaki, Touraj (2000). <i>Azerbaijan: Ethnicity and the Struggle for Power in Iran</i>. Hrair; Simonian, Hovann H. (2003). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=4_jdnke35AgC"><i>Troubled Waters: The Geopolitics of the Caspian Region</i></a>. I.B. Tauris. p.&#160;60. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-1-86064-922-6" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-1-86064-922-6"><bdi>978-1-86064-922-6</bdi></a>. <q>Until 1918, when the Musavat regime decided to name the newly independent state Azerbaijan, this designation had been used exclusively to identify the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azerbaijan_(Iran)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azerbaijan (Iran) (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Iranian province of Azerbaijan</a>.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Troubled+Waters%3A+The+Geopolitics+of+the+Caspian+Region&amp;rft.pages=60&amp;rft.pub=I.B.+Tauris&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-86064-922-6&amp;rft.aulast=Dekmejian&amp;rft.aufirst=R.+Hrair&amp;rft.au=Simonian%2C+Hovann+H.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D4_jdnke35AgC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Amsterdam_University_Press-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Amsterdam_University_Press_50-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFRezvani2014" class="citation book">Rezvani, Babak (2014). <i>Ethno-territorial conflict and coexistence in the caucasus, Central Asia and Fereydan: academisch proefschrift</i>. Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press. p.&#160;356. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-9048519286" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-9048519286"><bdi>978-9048519286</bdi></a>. <q>The region to the north of the river Araxes was not called Azerbaijan prior to 1918, unlike the region in northwestern Iran that has been called since so long ago.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ethno-territorial+conflict+and+coexistence+in+the+caucasus%2C+Central+Asia+and+Fereydan%3A+academisch+proefschrift&amp;rft.place=Amsterdam&amp;rft.pages=356&amp;rft.pub=Amsterdam+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-9048519286&amp;rft.aulast=Rezvani&amp;rft.aufirst=Babak&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-:1-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-:1_51-0">\xdb\xb5\xdb\xb1\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-:1_51-1">\xdb\xb5\xdb\xb1\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFFragner2001" class="citation book">Fragner, B.G. (2001). <i>Soviet Nationalism: An Ideological Legacy to the Independent Republics of Central Asia</i>. I.B. Tauris and Company. pp.&#160;13\xe2\x80\x9332. <q>In the post Islamic sense, Arran and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shirvan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shirvan (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Shirvan</a> are often distinguished, while in the pre-Islamic era, Arran or the western <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caucasian_Albania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caucasian Albania (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Caucasian Albania</a> roughly corresponds to the modern territory of the Republic of Azerbaijan. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soviet_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soviet Union (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">Soviet</a> era, in a breathtaking manipulation, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azerbaijan_(Iran)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azerbaijan (Iran) (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)">historical Azerbaijan</a> (northwestern <a href="/wiki/Iran" class="mw-redirect" title="Iran">Iran</a>) was reinterpreted as "South Azerbaijan" in order for the Soviets to lay territorial claim on historical Azerbaijan proper which is located in modern-day northwestern Iran.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Soviet+Nationalism%3A+An+Ideological+Legacy+to+the+Independent+Republics+of+Central+Asia&amp;rft.pages=13-32&amp;rft.pub=I.B.+Tauris+and+Company&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.aulast=Fragner&amp;rft.aufirst=B.G.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-52">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREFAtabaki2000" class="citation book">Atabaki, Touraj (2000). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=MybbePBf9YcC"><i>Azerbaijan: Ethnicity and the Struggle for Power in Iran</i></a>. I.B.Tauris. p.&#160;8. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/978-1-86064-554-9" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/978-1-86064-554-9"><bdi>978-1-86064-554-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290345"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-53">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREF\xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xdb\x8c2012" class="citation href="https://www.webcitation.org/6B7MkPFf9?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/persian/viewpoints/2012/09/post-311.html">\xc2\xab\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c. \xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2 <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/persian/viewpoints/2012/09/post-311.html">\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb5\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c</a> \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb2 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 <bdi>\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2-\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb0-\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb2</bdi></span>.</cite><span href="#cite_ref-54">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="CITEREF\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd8\xad\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c1382" class="citation book">\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd8\xad\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c\xd8\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3 (<bdi>\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb2</bdi>). <i>\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa2\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa\xda\x98\xdb\x8c\xda\xa9 \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</i>. \xd8\xaa\xd9\x87\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86: <sup><a href="#cite_ref-ToolAutoGenRef1_57-1">\xdb\xb5\xdb\xb7\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" Mustafayev</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-59"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-59">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" "Armenia between the Bolshevik hammer and Kemalist anvil". 1700 Years of Faithfulness: History of Armenia and its Churches. Moscow: FAM. <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/5-89831-013-4" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/5-89831-013-4">5-89831-013-4</a>.\n"<b>In March 1920 a terrible pogrom took place in Shushi, organized by Azerbaijanis with the support of Turkish forces. Azerbaijani and Soviet authorities during the decades will deny and try to hush up the mass killings of about 30000 Armenians</b>"</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-69"><span occupation of Shusha town, 30 thousand Armenians were massacred</b>". / \xd0\x98\xd0\xb3\xd0\xbe\xd1\x80\xd1\x8c \xd0\x91\xd0\xb0\xd0\xb1\xd0\xb0\xd0\xbd\xd0\xbe\xd0\xb2, \xd0\xa1\xd0\xb0\xd0\xbd\xd0\xba\xd1\x82-\xd0\x9f\xd0\xb5\xd1\x82\xd0\xb5\xd1\x80\xd0\xb1\xd1\x83\xd1\x80\xd0\xb3, 1992</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-70"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x85\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb5\xd8\xb1 <sup><a <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/%D8%AA%D8%AD%D9%88%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AA_%D8%B3%DB%8C%D8%A7%D8%B3%DB%8C_%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%85%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86" \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\x8c \xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb3\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87: <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/%D8%AA%D8%AD%D9%88%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AA_%D8%B3%DB%8C%D8%A7%D8%B3%DB%8C_%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%85%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86" \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8:\xd8\xaa\xd8\xad\xd9\x88\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\x8c \xd8\xaa\xd8\xad\xd9\x88\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd9\x82\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd8\xba \xd9\xbe\xd8\xb3 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2 \xd8\xa2\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb4\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb3\xd8\x8c \xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb3\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87: \xc2\xab\xd9\x88\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd9\x88\xd8\xb2\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xda\xa9\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd8\xac\xdb\x8c\xc2\xbb href="#cite_ref-Zamin_86-1">\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb6\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-Zamin_86-2">\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb6\xd9\xab\xdb\xb2</a></sup> <sup><a \xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2 <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.khabaronline.ir/news-29222.aspx">\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb5\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c</a> \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb8 \xda\x98\xd9\x88\xd8\xa6\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb1<span class="reference-accessdate">. \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x81\xd8\xaa\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 <bdi>\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb2 \xd9\x85\xd9\x87 href="#cite_ref-ng.ru_102-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ng.ru/politics/2011-01-24/1_karabah.html">\xd0\x9a\xd0\xb0\xd1\x80\xd0\xb0\xd0\xb1\xd0\xb0\xd1\x85\xd1\x81\xd0\xba\xd0\xb8\xd0\xb9 \xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87">\xd9\xbe\xdb\x8c\xd9\x88\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf \xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87</a></i>&#93;</span></sup></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-108">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tabnak.ir/fa/news/210320/\xd9\x85\xd9\x82\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa-\xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c-\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86-\xd8\xa8\xd9\x87-\xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84-\xd8\xaa\xd8\xac\xd8\xb2\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87-\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86-\xd9\x87\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xdb\x8c\xd9\x85">- \xd9\x85\xd9\x82\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86: \xd8\xa8\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xac\xd8\xb2\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x87\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xdb\x8c\xd9\x85 </a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-109">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://azerireport.com/index.php?option=com_content&amp;task=view&amp;id=2170&amp;Itemid=48">azerireport.com - Azerbaijan Belongs On Obama\'s List Of Violators Of Press Freedom</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-110">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/world/2014/10/141022_an_azerbaijan_politics_critics_detained">\'\xd9\x81\xd8\xb4\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xaa\xd9\x82\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb2\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaf \xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf\'</a> \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c \xd9\x81\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\x8c \xdb\xb3\xdb\xb0 \xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb9\xdb\xb3</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-111">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.intute.ac.uk/worldguide/html/819_people.html">Intute - World Guide - Azerbaijan</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-112"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-112">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/aj.html#People">CIA - The World Factbook</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-113">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://countrystudies.us/azerbaijan/18.htm">Azerbaijan - Population and Ethnic Composition</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Cornell,_Svante_E_2000._p_2622-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Cornell,_Svante_E_2000._p_2622_114-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Cornell, Svante E. Small Nations and Great Powers: A Study of Ethnopolitical Conflict in the Caucasus. Richmond, Surrey,, GBR: Curzon Press Limited, 2000. p 262. Where as officially the number of Lezgins registered as such in Azerbaijan is around \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 the Lezgins claim that the number of Lezgins registerd in Azerbaijan is much higher than this figure, some accounts showing over \xdb\xb7\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 Lezgins in Azerbaijan. These figures are denied by the Azerbaijani government, but in private many Azeris acknowledge the fact that the Lezgins \xe2\x80\x93 for that matter the Talysh or the Kurdish-population of Azerbaijan is far higher than the official figures... For the Lezgins in Azerbaijan, the existence of ethnic kin in Dagestan is of high importance. Nariman Ramazanov, one of the Lezgin political leaders, has argued that whereas the Talysh, Tats, and Kurds of Azerbaijan lost much of their language and ethnic identity, the Lezgins have been able to preserve theirs by their contacts with Dagestan, where there was naturally no policy of Azeri assimilation. \xe2\x80\xa6. The Lezgin problem remains one of the most acute and unpredictable of the contemporary Caucasus. This said, the conditions for a peaceful resolution of the conflict are present. No past conflict nor heavy mutual prejudices make management of the conflict impossible; nor has ethnic mobilization taken place to a significant extent. Hence there are no actual obstacles to a de-escalation of the conflict at the popular level. At the political level, however, the militancy of Sadval and the strict position of the Azeri government give cause for worry, and may prevent the settlement of the conflict through a compromise such as a freetrading zone. The Lezgin problem needs to be monitored and followed in closer detail, and its continued volatility is proven by the tension surrounding a recent Lezgin congress in Dagestan.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-115">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Christina Bratt (EDT) Paulston, Donald Peckham (eds.), Linguistic Minorities in Central and Eastern Europe, Multilingual Matters publisher, 1998, <a href="/wiki/%D8%B4%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%87_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%AF_%D8%A8%DB%8C%D9%86%E2%80%8C%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%84%D9%84%DB%8C_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8" title="\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/%D9%88%DB%8C%DA%98%D9%87:%D9%85%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%A8%D8%B9_%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8/1-85359-416-4" title="\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xda\x98\xd9\x87:\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8/1-85359-416-4">1-85359-416-4</a>, p. 106 1993 there was an attempt officially to restore the Latin script; very few people advocated the Arabic script. Kryzi and Khinalug speakers, as well as most Tsakhurs, are bilingual and tend to assimilate with the Azeris. The same is true of the Tat speakers, and slightly less about the Talysh. At least there is no official recognition, teaching or publishing in these languages in any form. Lezghins in Azerbaijan are struggling very determinedly for their linguistic revival, but with little success. Generally there is a prevailing policy of forceful assimilation of all minorities, including the Talysh, Tat, Kurds and Lezgins. There is little or no resistance to assimilation from the Kryzi, Khinalug, Tsakhurs or Tat, and not much resistance from the Talysh. There are some desperate efforts of resistance from the Udin, stubborn resistance from the Kurds, and an extremely active struggle from the Lezgins, who want to separate Lezgin populated districts both from Dagestan and Azerbaijan in order to create an autonomous republic with Lezgin as the state language.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-116">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Cornell, Svante E. Small Nations and Great Powers: A Study of Ethnopolitical Conflict in the Caucasus. Richmond, Surrey,, GBR: Curzon Press Limited, 2000. p 49. Further, Many Kurds, Lezgins, Talysh in Azerbaijan were assimilated into the Azerbaijani identity</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-117">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150922082955/http://www.un-az.org/doc/constitution.doc">\xc2\xab\xd9\x86\xd8\xb3\xd8\xae\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb4\xdb\x8c\xd9\x88 \xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87\xc2\xbb</a>. \xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2 <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.un-az.org/doc/constitution.doc">\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb5\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c</a> \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb2 \xd8\xb3\xd9\xbe\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb5<span class="reference-accessdate">. \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x81\xd8\xaa\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 <bdi>\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3 \xda\x98\xd9\x88\xd8\xa6\xd9\x86 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb6</bdi></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%AE%D9%87+%D8%A2%D8%B1%D8%B4%DB%8C%D9%88+%D8%B4%D8%AF%D9%87&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.un-az.org%2Fdoc%2Fconstitution.doc&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290294"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-118">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://ec.europa.eu/world/enp/pdf/progress2009/sec09_512_en.pdf">http://ec.europa.eu/world/enp/pdf/progress2009/sec09_512_en.pdf</a> The legislative and institutional framework for the protection of national minorities remains insufficient. Issues of concern include the lack of comprehensive anti-discriminatory legislation and limited possibilities for national minorities to effectively channel their views and concerns to the authorities, as well as reported cases of intolerance faced by persons or organisations advocating minority rights. Some national minorities continue to face discrimination. Like last year, there was no progress towards ratification of the Protocol n\xc2\xb0 \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2 of the ECHR on the general prohibition of discrimination or of the European Charter on Minority Languages.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-119">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Statistical Yearbook of Azerbaijan 2006</i>, State Statistical Committee, Baku, table 2.6, p. 69</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-120">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180328034119/http://www.azerbaijan.az/_GeneralInfo/_Population/_population_e.html">\xc2\xabThe Population of Azerbaijan\xc2\xbb</a>. \xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2 <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.azerbaijan.az/_GeneralInfo/_Population/_population_e.html">\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb5\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c</a> \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb8 \xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb3 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8<span class="reference-accessdate">. \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x81\xd8\xaa\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 <bdi>\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb7 \xd8\xa7\xd9\x88\xd8\xaa \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3</bdi></span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Population+of+Azerbaijan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.azerbaijan.az%2F_GeneralInfo%2F_Population%2F_population_e.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Ffa.wikipedia.org%3A%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%87%D9%88%D8%B1%DB%8C+%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r28290294"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Azer2009-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Azer2009_121-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.azstat.org/statinfo/demoqraphic/en/AP_/1_5.xls">Censuses of Republic of Azerbaijan 1979, 1989, 1999, 2009</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-autogenerated1-122"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-autogenerated1_122-0">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb2\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-autogenerated1_122-1">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb2\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/aj.html">\xd8\xb3\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7 - \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-123"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-123">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/world/countries/azerbaijan.html#land">[\xdb\xb2]</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-di-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-di_124-0">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb4\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-di_124-1">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb4\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cgie.org.ir/shavadn.asp?id=391&amp;avaid=2276">\xc2\xab\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd9\x8e\xd8\xb1\xd9\x92\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd9\x92\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\x8c \xd8\xac\xd9\x8f\xd9\x85\xd9\x92\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xc2\xbb</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20121029031059/http://www.cgie.org.ir/shavadn.asp?id=391&amp;avaid=2276">\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87</a>  \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb9 \xd8\xa7\xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2 \xd8\xaa\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3\xd8\xb7 <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" class="mw-redirect" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>\xd8\x8c <a href="/wiki/%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%B4%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%87%D9%94_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86" class="mw-redirect" title="\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xb4\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xb4\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a>\xd8\x8c \xd9\x88\xd8\xa8\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x87 <a href="/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B1%DA%A9%D8%B2_%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B1%D8%A9%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%81_%D8%A8%D8%B2%D8%B1%DA%AF_%D8%A7%D8%B3%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85%DB%8C" title="\xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xda\xa9\xd8\xb2 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa6\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa9\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x81 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xb2\xd8\xb1\xda\xaf \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c">\xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xda\xa9\xd8\xb2 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa6\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa9\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x81 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xb2\xd8\xb1\xda\xaf \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-125"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-125">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://www.eva.mpg.de/genetics/pdf/Y-paper.pdf">http://www.eva.mpg.de/genetics/pdf/Y-paper.pdf</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Cornell,_Svante_E_2000._p_262-126"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-Cornell,_Svante_E_2000._p_262_126-0">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Cornell, Svante E. Small Nations and Great Powers: A Study of Ethnopolitical Conflict in the Caucasus. Richmond, Surrey,, GBR: Curzon Press Limited, 2000. p 262.\nWhere as officially the number of Lezgins registered as such in Azerbaijan is around \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 the Lezgins claim that the number of Lezgins registerd in Azerbaijan is much higher than this figure, some accounts showing over \xdb\xb7\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 Lezgins in Azerbaijan. These figures are denied by the Azerbaijani government, but in private many Azeris acknowledge the fact that the Lezgins \xe2\x80\x93 for that matter the Talysh or the Kurdish-population of Azerbaijan is far higher than the official figures...\nFor the Lezgins in Azerbaijan, the existence of ethnic kin in Dagestan is of high importance. Nariman Ramazanov, one of the Lezgin political leaders, has argued that whereas the Talysh, Tats, and Kurds of Azerbaijan lost much of their language and ethnic identity, the Lezgins have been able to preserve theirs by their contacts with Dagestan, where there was naturally no policy of Azeri assimilation. \xe2\x80\xa6. The Lezgin problem remains one of the most acute and unpredictable of the contemporary Caucasus. This said, the conditions for a peaceful resolution of the conflict are present. No past conflict nor heavy mutual prejudices make management of the conflict impossible; nor has ethnic mobilization taken place to a significant extent. Hence there are no actual obstacles to a de-escalation of the conflict at the popular level. At the political level, however, the militancy of Sadval and the strict position of the Azeri government give cause for worry, and may prevent the settlement of the conflict through a compromise such as a freetrading zone. The Lezgin problem needs to be monitored and followed in closer detail, and its continued volatility is proven by the tension surrounding a recent Lezgin congress in Dagestan.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-ToolAutoGenRef3-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-ToolAutoGenRef3_127-0">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb7\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-ToolAutoGenRef3_127-1">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb7\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=Azerbaijan">Ethnologue report for Azerbaijan</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-128">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/dybcensus/V2_table4.xls">27 \xd9\x81\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 1999 census of Azerbaijan</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-129">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Cornell, Svante E. Small Nations and Great Powers: A Study of Ethnopolitical Conflict in the Caucasus. Richmond, Surrey,, GBR: Curzon Press Limited, 2000\npg 259:\nFor the lezgins in Azerbaijan, the existence of ethnic kin in Daghestan is of high importance. Nariman Ramazonov, one of the Lezgin political leaders, has argued that whereas the Talysh, Tats and Kurds of Azerbaijan lost much of their language and ethnic identity, the Lezgins have been able to preserve theirs by their contacts with Daghestan, where there was no natural policy of Azeri assimilation.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-osce.org-130"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-osce.org_130-0">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb0\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-osce.org_130-1">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb0\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">Hema Kotecha, Islamic and Ethnic Identities in Azerbaijan: Emerging trends and tensions, OSCE, Baku, July 2006\n<a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.osce.org/documents/ob/2006/08/23087_en.pdf">[\xdb\xb3]</a>\nAccording to the census of 1926, there were \xdb\xb7\xdb\xb7\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb9 Talysh in Soviet Azerbaijan. 1959 and following censuses do not mention the Talysh who became officially Azerbaijanis and this has been the case ever since. Nevertheless, the Talysh language was\nacknowledged as a mother tongue by \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb5\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 people in 1959. According to data from 1983, nearly \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 Talysh live in Iran.\nOnly in 1989 did the census register the Talysh ethnicity. \xdb\xb7\xdb\xb6\xd9\xac\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 in Azerbaijan is the 1999 official population, undoubtedly an under-representation (given the problems with registering as Talysh) and some claim a current population of \xdb\xb5\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 living in the southern regions of Azerbaijan.131 (Talysh also inhabit the north-western areas of Iran \xe2\x80\x93 Gilan province and some of Ardebil).</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-taleshan.com-131"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-taleshan.com_131-0">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb1\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-taleshan.com_131-1">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb1\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">\xd9\x85\xd8\xac\xd9\x84\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c \xd8\xaf\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87\xdb\xb3/(\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb7\xdb\xb1) \xd8\xa8\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7(Bethesda)\xd8\xa2\xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xda\xa9\xd8\xa7/ \xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xd9\x87\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xdb\xb6\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb2 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xdb\xb6\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb1/ \xd8\xb3\xd8\xb1\xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaa \xd8\xaa\xd9\x84\xd8\xae \xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd8\xb4\xe2\x80\x8c\xd9\x87\xd8\xa7 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb4\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c-\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaf\xd8\xba\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x88\xd8\xb7\xd9\x84\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd9\x87! \xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7 \xd8\xaa\xd9\x82\xd9\x84\xd8\xa8 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xb2\xd9\x88\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1/\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xda\xaf\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86/\n<a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.taleshan.com/talesh-sh.htm">[\xdb\xb4]</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100726165608/http://www.taleshan.com/talesh-sh.htm">\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87</a>  \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb6 \xda\x98\xd9\x88\xd8\xa6\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb0 \xd8\xaa\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3\xd8\xb7 <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" class="mw-redirect" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-132">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Cornell, Svante E. Small Nations and Great Powers: A Study of Ethnopolitical Conflict in the Caucasus. Richmond, Surrey,, GBR: Curzon Press Limited, 2000. p 308.\nIn the south there is a substantial community of the Iranian ethnic group, of Talysh, possibly some \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 \xe2\x80\x93\xdb\xb4\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 people.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-133"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-133">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Hema Kotecha, Islamic and Ethnic Identities in Azerbaijan: Emerging trends and tensions, OSCE, Baku, July 2006\n<a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.osce.org/documents/ob/2006/08/23087_en.pdf">[\xdb\xb5]</a>\npg 8\nThe suppression of Talysh identity (predominant in the south) during the Soviet period led to a situation in which the Talysh ethnicity is unquantifiable (yet the population with the largest growth rate in the country). This is also partly due to a reluctance to claim Talysh identity (influenced by a stigma against publicly pronouncing non-Azerbaijani identity) and the diminishing use of Talysh language, except in places which are relatively remote and unintegrated. Nationalists seem fairly marginalised.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-134"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-134">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Gernot Windfuhr, "Persian Grammer: history and state of its study", Walter de Gruyter, 1979. pg 4:""Tat- Persian spoken in the East Caucasus""</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-135"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-135">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/dybcensus/V2_table4.xls">http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/dybcensus/V2_table4.xls</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-Natalia_G._Volkova_1996-136"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">\xe2\x86\x91 <sup><a href="#cite_ref-Natalia_G._Volkova_1996_136-0">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb6\xd9\xab\xdb\xb0</a></sup> <sup><a href="#cite_ref-Natalia_G._Volkova_1996_136-1">\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb6\xd9\xab\xdb\xb1</a></sup></span> <span class="reference-text">\xe2\x80\x9cIn the nineteenth century the Tats were settled in large homogeneous groups. The intensive processes of assimilation by the Turkic-speaking Azerbaijanis cut back the territory and numbers of the Tats. In 1886 they numbered more than \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xd9\xac\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 in Azerbaijan and \xdb\xb3\xd9\xac\xdb\xb6\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 in Daghestan. According to the census of 1926 the number of Tats in Azerbaijan (despite the effect of natural increase) had dropped to \xdb\xb2\xdb\xb8\xd9\xac\xdb\xb5\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0, although there were also \xdb\xb3\xdb\xb8\xd9\xac\xdb\xb3\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0 \xe2\x80\x9cAzerbaijanis\xe2\x80\x9dwith Tat as their native language. \xe2\x80\x9d\n(Natalia G. Volkova \xe2\x80\x9cTats\xe2\x80\x9din Encyclopedia of World Culture, Editor: David Publisher, New York: G.K. Hall, Prentice Hall International, 1991-1996).</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-137"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-137">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">Abbas Qoli Agha Bakikhanov, a 19th century literary figure from the Caucasia mentions in his Golestan Iram large number of Tats in the area around Baku:\nThere are eight villages in Tabarsaran which are: Jalqan, Rukan, Maqatir, Kamakh, Ridiyan, Homeydi, Mata\'i, and Bilhadi. They are in the environs of a city that Anushiravan built near the wall of Darband. Its remains are still there. They speak the Tat language, which is one of the languages of Old Persia. It is clear that they are from the people of Fars and after its destruction they settled in those villages...The districts situated between the two cities of Shamakhi and Qodyal, which is now the city of Qobbeh, include Howz, Lahej, and Qoshunlu in Shirvan and Barmak, Sheshpareh and the lower part of Boduq in Qobbeh, and all the country of Baku, except six villages of Turkmen, speak Tat. it becomes apparent from this that they originate from Fars.\n\n(Floor, Willem. and Javadi, Hasan. i(\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb9), "The Heavenly Rose-Garden: A History of Shirvan &amp; Daghestan by Abbas Qoli Aqa Bakikhanov, Mage Publishers, 2009)\n\nOriginal Persian:\n\xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8 \xd9\x85\xd8\xb0\xda\xa9\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xa2\xd9\x85\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa: \xd9\x87\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaa \xd9\x82\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xb7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb3\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xda\xa9\xd9\x87 \xd8\xac\xd9\x84\xd9\x82\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xda\xa9\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84 \xd9\x88 \xd9\x85\xd9\x82\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x88 \xda\xa9\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xae \xd9\x88 \xd8\xb2\xdb\x8c\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xad\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c \xd9\x88 \xd9\x85\xd8\xb7\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb9\xdb\x8c \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xd9\x84\xd8\xad\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd8\x8c \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xad\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xd8\xb4\xd9\x87\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xda\xa9\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xd8\xb4\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x85\xd8\xad\xd9\x84 \xd9\x85\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb5\xd9\x84 \xd8\xa8\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf \xd8\xaa\xd8\xb9\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1 \xda\xa9\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa8\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa2\xd8\xab\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xa2\xd9\x86 \xd9\x87\xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xd8\xb2 \xd9\x85\xd8\xb9\xd9\x84\xd9\x88\xd9\x85 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb2\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf. \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb6\xd8\xa7\xd9\x8b \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb9 \xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8 \xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaf \xd8\xb4\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa2\xd9\x85\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa: \xd9\x85\xd8\xad\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd9\x82\xd8\xb9 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xa8\xd9\x84\xd9\x88\xda\xa9\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd8\xae\xdb\x8c \xd9\x88 \xd9\x82\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84 \xda\xa9\xd9\x87 \xd8\xad\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7 \xd8\xb4\xd9\x87\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x82\xd8\xa8\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\x8c \xd9\x85\xd8\xab\xd9\x84 \xd8\xad\xd9\x88\xd8\xb6 \xd9\x88 \xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd9\x87\xd8\xac \xd9\x88 \xd9\x82\xd8\xb4\xd9\x88\xd9\x86\xd9\x84\xd9\x88 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xb4\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xd9\x85\xda\xa9 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xb4\xd8\xb4 \xd9\xbe\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88 \xd9\xbe\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xaf\xd9\x88\xd9\x82 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x82\xd8\xa8\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xaa\xd9\x85\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85 \xd9\x85\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xda\xa9\xd8\xaa \xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xda\xa9\xd9\x88 \xd8\xb3\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd8\xb4\xd8\xb4 \xd9\x82\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xda\xa9\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd8\x8c \xd9\x87\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb2\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xe2\x80\xa6 \xd9\x82\xd8\xb3\xd9\x85 \xd9\x82\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c \xd9\x85\xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xda\xa9\xd8\xaa \xd9\x82\xd8\xa8\xd9\x87 \xd8\xb3\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd9\x82\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xd8\xae\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xd9\x82 \xda\xa9\xd9\x87 \xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c \xd8\xb9\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xad\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd9\x88 \xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd8\xad\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87\xd9\x94 \xd8\xb3\xd9\x85\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88 \xda\xa9\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd9\x88 \xd9\x85\xd8\xad\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84 \xd8\xb7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xd8\xb3\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xda\xa9\xd9\x87 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xad\xd9\x85\xd8\xaf\xd9\x84\xd9\x88 \xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb4\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf \xd8\xa8\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb5\xd8\xb7\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd8\xad\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xb7\xd9\x82\xd9\x87\xd8\x8c \xd8\xb2\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x85\xd8\xae\xd8\xb5\xd9\x88\xd8\xb5 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa7\xd9\x87\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1\xda\xa9\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb2\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7 \xd9\x85\xd8\xba\xd9\x88\xd9\x84 \xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xaf.\n\n(Gulistan-i Iram, Baki Khanuf, \xe2\x80\x9cGulistan-i Iram\xe2\x80\x9d, matn-i ilmi - intiqadi bi-sayy va ihtimam: Abd al-Karim Ali-zadah[va digaran],Bakku: Idarah-i intisharat-i Ilm, 1970.)</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-138"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><a href="#cite_ref-138">\xe2\x86\x91</a></span> <span class="reference-text">\xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86-\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x85 - \xd9\x85\xd8\xaa\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb9\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c - \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb4\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa \xd8\xb9\xd9\x84\xd9\x85\n(Gulistan-i Iram, Baki Khanuf, \xe2\x80\x9cGulistan-i Iram\xe2\x80\x9d, matn-i ilmi - intiqadi bi-sayy va class="cs1-code">&#124;\xd8\xb9\xd9\x86\xd9\x88\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86= \xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7 &#124;title=</code> \xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7 \xd8\xae\xd8\xa7\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c (<a href="/wiki/%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%87%D9%86%D9%85%D8%A7:%D8%AE%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%84%DA%AF%D9%88%DB%8C_%DB%8C%D8%A7%D8%AF%DA%A9%D8%B1%D8%AF#citation_missing_title" href="http://azer.com/aiweb/categories/magazine/63_folder/63_articles/63_bibiheybat.html">6.3 The Bibi-Heybat Mosque: When Legends Shape Reality</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div></small><small><ul><li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/aj.html\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb7\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa">\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd9\x85\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a></li>\n<li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.is/20121212062804/lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+az0034)">\xda\xa9\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd8\xa8\xd8\xae\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd9\x87 \xda\xa9\xd9\x86\xda\xaf\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa2\xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xda\xa9\xd8\xa7</a></li></ul></small><small></small><p><small></small>\n</p>\n<h2><span style="text-align:right;border-right-width:2px;border-right-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em"><div>\n<a class="mw-selflink id="*_\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa\xd8\xad\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87_\xda\xaf\xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xda\xa9\xdb\x8c_\xd8\xa7\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7_*_\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa\xd8\xad\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87_\xd8\xa7\xd9\x82\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb5\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c_\xd8\xa7\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7_*_\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaa\xd8\xad\xd8\xa7\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87_\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87_\xd9\x88_\xd8\xa8\xd9\x84\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3">\n<ul><li><a \xd8\xb9\xd9\x87\xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87 \xd9\x81\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xda\xa9\xd9\x86\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xd8\x9b \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd9\x81\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\xb3\xd9\x87 (\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb7)</a> \xe2\x80\xa2 <a href="/wiki/%D8%B9%D9%87%D8%AF%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%87_%D9%85%D8%AC%D9%85%D9%84" \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 (\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb9)</a> \xe2\x80\xa2 <a href="/wiki/%D8%B9%D9%87%D8%AF%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%81%D8%B5%D9%84" title="\xd8\xb9\xd9\x87\xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87 \xd9\x85\xd9\x81\xd8\xb5\xd9\x84">\xd8\xb9\xd9\x87\xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87 \xd9\x85\xd9\x81\xd8\xb5\xd9\x84\xd8\x9b \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 (\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb2)</a> \xe2\x80\xa2 \n<a href="/wiki/%D8%B9%D9%87%D8%AF%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%87_%DA%AF%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86" title="\xd8\xb9\xd9\x87\xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87 \xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xd8\xb9\xd9\x87\xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87 \xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd8\x9b \xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd9\x88 \xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87 (\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb3)</a> \xe2\x80\xa2 <a href="/wiki/%D8%B9%D9%87%D8%AF%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%87_%DB%B1%DB%B8%DB%B2%DB%B2_%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86_%D9%88_%D8%A7%D9%86%DA%AF%D9%84%DB%8C%D8%B3" \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb3">\xd8\xb9\xd9\x87\xd8\xaf\xd9\x86\xd8\xa7\xd9\x85\xd9\x87 \xd8\xb4\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2\xd8\x9b \xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 (\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb2\xdb\xb8)</a> \xe2\x80\xa2 <a href="/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%AF%D9%87_%D9%BE%D8%A7%D8%B1%DB%8C%D8%B3" title="\xd9\x85\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7\xd9\x87\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb3 (\xdb\xb1\xdb\xb8\xdb\xb5\xdb\xb6)</a>  \xe2\x80\xa2 <a \xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xda\xaf\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb3 ( \xdb\xb1\xdb\xb9\xdb\xb0\xdb\xb7)</a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">\xd9\x85\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb7</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:right;border-right-width:2px;border-right-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div title="\xd9\x85\xd9\x88\xd8\xb2\xdb\x8c\xda\xa9\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xd8\xb2">\xd9\x85\xd9\x88\xd8\xb2\xdb\x8c\xda\xa9\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86\xd8\xb2</a></span></li>\n<li><span class="uid"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://catalog.archives.gov/id/10045248">\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xda\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c \xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xd8\xb1\xd8\xb3\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa \xd9\x88 \xdb\x8c\xda\xa9\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2 \xd8\xb2\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86\xd9\x87\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd8\xb1\xd8\xb3\xd9\x85\xdb\x8c \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 <a href="/wiki/%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%BA%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86" title="\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xba\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xba\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a> \xd9\x88 \xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb2 \xd8\xa8\xd9\x87 \xd8\xb7\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1 \xda\xaf\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf\xd9\x87\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 <a href="/wiki/%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86" title="\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a> \xd8\xb3\xd8\xae\xd9\x86 \xda\xaf\xd9\x81\xd8\xaa\xd9\x87 \xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf\xd8\x8c \xd8\xa8\xd9\x87 \xd8\xae\xd8\xb5\xd9\x88\xd8\xb5 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 <a href="/wiki/%D8%A2%D8%B0%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AC%D8%A7%D9%86" title="\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a>. \xd9\x87\xd9\x85\xda\x86\xd9\x86\xdb\x8c\xd9\x86 \xd8\xaf\xd8\xb1 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xb1\xd8\xae\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa7\xd8\xb2 \xd8\xa8\xd8\xae\xd8\xb4\xe2\x80\x8c\xd9\x87\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c <a href="/wiki/%D8%AA%D8%B1%DA%A9%DB%8C%D9%87" title="\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1\xda\xa9\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87">\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb1\xda\xa9\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87</a>\xd8\x8c <a href="/wiki/%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%87" title="\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87">\xd8\xb1\xd9\x88\xd8\xb3\xdb\x8c\xd9\x87</a> \xd9\x88 <a href="/wiki/%DA%AF%D8%B1%D8%AC%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86" title="\xda\xaf\xd8\xb1\xd8\xac\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xda\xaf\xd8\xb1\xd8\xac\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a> \xd8\xb5\xd8\xad\xd8\xa8\xd8\xaa \xd9\x85\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb4\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf.</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>\n<div role="navigation" class="navbox" \xd8\xb9\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x82-\xd8\xb9\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86">\xd9\x85\xd9\x86\xd8\xb7\xd9\x82\xd9\x87 \xd8\xa8\xdb\x8c\xe2\x80\x8c\xd8\xb7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x81 title="\xd8\xb9\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x82">\xd8\xb9\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa7\xd9\x82</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%B3%D8%B9%D9%88%D8%AF%DB%8C" title="\xd8\xb9\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86 \xd8\xb3\xd8\xb9\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf\xdb\x8c">\xd8\xb9\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb3\xd8\xaa\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a></li></ul></li>\n<li><a \xd8\xb4\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7">\xda\xa9\xd8\xb4\xd8\xaa\xd8\xb2\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd9\x87\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c \xd8\xb4\xd8\xa8\xd8\xb9\xd8\xa7</a>\n<ul><li><a href="/w/index.php?title=%D8%A8%D8%AD%D8%AB_%D8%A7%D9%84%DA%AF%D9%88:%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%AA%D8%AE%D8%AA%E2%80%8C%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C_%D8%A2%D8%B3%DB%8C%D8%A7&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" (\xd8\xb5\xd9\x81\xd8\xad\xd9\x87 \xd9\x88\xd8\xac\xd9\x88\xd8\xaf \xd9\x86\xd8\xaf\xd8\xa7\xd8\xb1\xd8\xaf)"><abbr title="\xd8\xa8\xd8\xad\xd8\xab \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a></li>\n<li><a \xd9\x85\xd9\x84\xdb\x8c \xd8\xac\xd9\x85\xd9\x87\xd9\x88\xd8\xb1\xdb\x8c \xd8\xa2\xd8\xb0\xd8\xb1\xd8\xa8\xd8\xa7\xdb\x8c\xd8\xac\xd8\xa7\xd9\x86</a></li>\n<li><a
